Description: South Ionian pottery mug, reconstructed from several fragments with added plaster; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed black below; exterior: reserved on upper body and interior surface of handle; glazed black on lower half of cup, flat base, and on exterior surface of handle.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Robinson lists the cup as coming from the Sanctuary of Hera but Fairbanks mentions only Naukratis (published in Fairbanks 1928, 220, pl. 37, no 337). The shape of the cup is typical of Hera Cups from this period. However, unlike Hera cups which have dipinto dedications to the goddess, this cup has none. Other similar cups were found in the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus and thus this shape is not exclusive to Hera. Despite this, both the crude slip and rather coarse fabric are typical of Hera cups and so the cup may have been produced on Samos. As Schlotzhauer points out, if the cup does indeed come from the Sanctuary of Hera, it provides evidence that it was not a requirement that all cups of this shape which were then left as votives to Hera should have a dedication to the goddess. For parallels with Hera cups, see British Museum 1888,0601.401, 1888, 0601.402, 1888.0601.403, and 1888,0601.405. For parallels regarding South Ionian mugs, see Cambrdige Fitzwilliam GR.229.1899. Following Furtwängler's typology of Samian Hera cups, the sherd possibly belongs with his Type I-III (Furtwängler 1989 88, fig. 14). Furtwängler, A.E. and Kienast, H.J. 1989, Samos III: Der Nordbau im Heraion von Samos, Bonn.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 228, no. 144)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 120, pl. XXXVII, no. 337)
Schlotzhauer 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus Naukratis (p. 116, Nau 78, pl. 16 e-f)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.890) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.5940 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
